label: A_cP8_198_2a-001
title: $\alpha$-N ($P2_{1}3$) Structure
comments:
Solid nitrogen is found in three forms (Mills, 1969; Donohue, 1974): \begin{itemize} \item The ground state $\alpha$-N structure, stable below 35.6K, found either in a \href{current_web_home_dir/A_cP8_205_c-001}{centrosymmetric} or a \href{current_web_home_dir/A_cP8_198_2a-001}{non-centrosymmetric} cubic structure. \item The hexagonal $\beta$-phase, which has freely rotating N$_{2}$ molecules and is stable up to the melting point, and \item High-pressure \href{current_web_home_dir/A_tP4_136_f-001}{$\gamma$-N}, stable above 355 MPa. \end{itemize} ~ \vspace{-.25in} 
 There is considerable controversy about the crystal structure of $\alpha$-N, as outlined in (Donohue, 1982, pp. 280-285). This page assumes the non-centrosymmetric $P2_{1}3$ \#198 structure. The other possibility is the \href{current_web_home_dir/A_cP8_205_c-001}{$Pa\overline{3}$ \#205 structure}, where the N$_{2}$ dimers are centered on an inversion site. (Venables, 1974) makes a convincing case that the ground state is $Pa\overline{3}$, but we present both structures. Density Functional Theory calculations show no appreciable difference in energy between the $Pa_{3}$ and $P2_{1}3$ structures. (Mehl, 2015)
